citation.article-title: Chryseobacterium hungaricum sp. nov., isolated from hydrocarbon-contaminated soil.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Chryseobacterium hungaricum sp. nov.
Chryseobacterium hungaricum (hun.ga′ri.cum. L. neut. adj. hungaricum from Hungary).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, non-motile rods with rounded ends, devoid of flagella, approximately 0.5 μm in diameter and 0.9 μm in length.
Aerobic.
Oxidase- and catalase-positive.
Good growth is observed on TGE, TSA and nutrient agars, but not on MacConkey agar.
Colonies are shiny, 3–4 mm in diameter, circular with entire edges and creamy in consistency, becoming mucous after 2 days incubation on nutrient agar.
Bright yellow flexirubin-type pigments are produced (KOH-test-positive).
Growth occurs at 5–37 °C (optimum, 28–30 °C), but not at 42 °C.
The pH range for growth is 6.0–10.0 (optimum, pH 6.5–7.5).
Growth occurs with 0–2 % NaCl (optimum, 0–1 %).
Acid is produced from lactose, maltose, trehalose and d-xylose, but not from l-arabinose, fructose, glycerol or mannitol.
Glucose, mannose and maltose are utilized as sole carbon sources, but arabinose, mannitol, N-acetylglucosamine, gluconate, caprate, adipate, malate, citrate and phenylacetate are not.
Indole is produced.
β-Glucosidase activity is present, but urease activity is absent.
Nitrate and nitrite are not reduced.
The predominant fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, summed feature 3 (comprising C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH) and iso-C17 : 0 3-OH.
MK-6 is the predominant respiratory quinone; MK-5 occurs in small amounts.
PE, PG, DPG and PS are present as polar lipids.
The type strain is CHB-20pT (=NCAIM B2269T=DSM 19684T), isolated from hydrocarbon-contaminated soil in Hungary.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 37.5 mol%.
